awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:NCS-FO: How cognitive maps potentiate new learning: constraining a computational model by decoding the thoughts of superior memorists
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will break new ground in the study of memory by partnering with competitors in the USA Memory Championship.  These competitors are not savants, but instead are well-practiced in the use of mnemonic techniques and, as a result, exhibit enhanced powers of memory on a range of real-world tasks, such as memorizing the items on a shopping list.  All of these techniques rely on the practitioner structuring prior knowledge in very specific ways that facilitate the incorporation of new information.  By scanning the brains of these trained memorists with functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and comparing their brain activity to participants who are learning these mnemonic systems for the first time, the researchers will identify principles for optimal scaffolding: How can prior knowledge be structured and used to most effectively support new learning? Identifying these principles will improve our fundamental understanding of real world-memory and will also lay the foundation for future educational interventions based on these principles. This project is funded by Integrative Strategies for Understanding Neural and Cognitive Systems (NCS), a multidisciplinary program jointly supported by the Directorates for Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE), Education and Human Resources (EHR), Engineering (ENG), and Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences (SBE). 
 
The goal of the project is to extend theories of memory to address how people can optimally use cognitive maps (structured prior knowledge) to support new learning. Reinforcement learning algorithms will be applied to computational models of memory to make predictions about which strategies will result in the best performance, factoring in biological constraints on the human memory system. Model predictions about optimal memory strategies will be tested using fMRI data from memory experts who have spent years optimizing their ability to bind arbitrary information to an internal cognitive map (a “memory palace”), and who therefore serve as a unique comparison group for optimized memory models; these subjects will be compared to a sample of young adult subjects who are being trained to use these memorization techniques. New neuroimaging approaches developed by the researchers will allow them to map the brain patterns corresponding to each room of the memory palace and the patterns corresponding to each individual memory, and then track the activation of these patterns as subjects recall memories using mental walks through their palace. Results of these analyses will be used to test detailed model predictions about how memory training will alter the structure and use of subjects’ cognitive maps, and how these changes relate to memory performance. As a final test of the models, the researchers will use neural measurements of individual subjects’ cognitive maps to predict which specific items they will recall. By examining how prior knowledge is deployed to support learning in experts and novices at a much finer resolution than was previously possible, this work will provide the foundation for understanding why wide variations in memory performance exist across individuals and how memory can be improved, paving the way for targeted interventions to improve memory performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Current theories of human memory have been developed primarily based on experiments in which people memorize lists of random words or pictures. In the real world, however, we can connect our experiences to our knowledge about the world and use these connections to create strong memories. A dinnertime conversation with friends, for example, could be situated within a spatial map (the location of the restaurant), a social network (of our relationships to our companions), or an event script (our knowledge about how restaurant experiences usually unfold). In our project, we sought to understand how the brain tracks this background knowledge, connects new experiences to our existing knowledge, and accesses these event memories in the future.

 

We developed a new experimental paradigm for studying this process, based on a memory technique called the "Method of Loci" or "Memory Palace" technique. This mnemonic device, which has been used for centuries, taps into the exact memory mechanisms we hoped to study, since it involves creating a route through an imagined sequence of spatial anchors ("loci") and then attaching information to this mental map. We enrolled 25 participants in a month-long study that consisted of: a pre-training session to measure their baseline memory performance; two weeks of training to use the Method of Loci technique (with a coach from the USA Memory Championship); an intermediate neuroimaging (functional MRI) session to measure the neural representations of their mental map and how they formed new memories; two additional weeks of practice; and a final two-day neuroimaging session. We also recruited 5 memorization experts (recent finalists in national memory competitions) to participate in a two-day neuroimaging session. Our final fMRI dataset consisted of 3,000 memories in which an item being remembered was being attached to a spatial map. Our participants were very effective at using this technique to remember lists of words, and were able to remember over 90% of the words on 20- or 40-item lists.

 

Measuring the activity patterns for each locus, each word, and the combined word-locus memory, we discovered that brain regions including the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) play an important role in attaching a word to a mental map. Creating a memory required not only bringing the word and the map to mind, but also thinking about the relationship between the two and recording specific details about this relationship. This "glue" between the current experience and past knowledge was in fact the largest component of the memory representation, and reflected the specific mental imagery that each person generated when creating their memory. We also found that the maps themselves changed in experts, with stronger links between the loci that allowed experts to move between them more quickly. We will be publicly sharing our neuroimaging dataset as well as the verbal recall data we collected, to allow other researchers in the field to test hypotheses about the memory system.

 

We have also created prototype computational models that can simulate this process of forming memories in context and explain based on theoretical principles why the brain uses this particular strategy. We built a computational model of how people search their memories after studying a list of items and found that the optimal strategy aligns with the Method of Loci technique, demonstrating that this technique provides a recipe for engaging the memory system in the most effective way. We are currently extending this model to better understand why applying the Method of Loci is more effective in some individuals than others. Finally, we have begun to map the components of these models onto neural systems in the brain. Unlike previous computational theories that have focused primarily on the function of the hippocampus, our paradigm (in which more extensive contextual information exists as the “glue” to scaffold new information to old knowledge) has allowed us to investigate how mPFC and other neocortical regions naturally organize memory activity to use prior associations to enhance the binding process.

 

This project created a new partnership between memory researchers and people who have spent years honing their memorization skills. In the past, there has been, surprisingly, very little cross-fertilization between these two communities, with relatively few studies on memory experts or even novices trained on mnemonic techniques.  This grant allowed for new dialog between neuroscientists, top memorists in the country, and the public, through events such as the recent USA Memory Tournament of Champions held on Nov. 10, 2024 at MIT’s Kresge Auditorium. The competitors tested their skills in a series of memorization challenges, interspersed with public presentations by memory researchers including co-PI Ajemian. As a result of this project there is now a new scientific infrastructure to study human memory from the point of view of mnemonic techniques.
